conbody.p: The NCC supports three containerized network functions (CNFs) â€“ Service Manager (SM), Managed Element (ME), and Integrated SM and ME (IG).
The SM CNF hosts the Service Manager application, which is used for API access, provisioning, data access, and access to various interfaces of external systems.
The ME CNF hosts the Charging application, which provides all the business logic for the charging function in NCC.

The Integrated SM and ME CNF groups all the functionality of SM and ME within a single CNF. The IG solution delivers the smallest overall footprint since both ME and SM functions are able to share the same set of common containers

section.title: Service Manager CNF
section.p: The centralized Service Manager CNF manages all the MEs in the network. SM is a highly scalable front-end access to the network of NCC CNFs. It hosts all GUI, provisioning, and external API access. SM runs in an active-active deployment with data replication between the SMs. SM provisions and is aware of the location of all subscriber or device records. SM contains the subscriber location data, but not the actual records themselves. Configuration management of NCC must go through SM. Direct interaction with MEs for configuration management is not available.

note.p: While SM provides active/active operation with data replication between the two SMs, Nokia recommends that back-to-back transactions for the same subscriber/device or set of devices within a particular group are all sent to the same SM to avoid race conditions with data replication.

section.title: Managed Element CNF
section.p: The Managed Element CNF provides the charging function in NCC. ME includes the Charging application and the database for managing all subscriber and device records, including the dynamic data updated as a result of charging transactions. ME produces charging data records (CDRs) to record the details of all transactions.

section.title: Integrated SM and ME CNF
section.p: One way to reduce the overall NCC footprint in an operator network is to deploy an integrated SM and ME CNF, rather than two separate and independent CNFs. The SM and ME provide very different network functions, however, the underlying infrastructure for those two functions share a common foundation. By deploying both SM and ME together on a single platform infrastructure, the overall footprint is reduced.
